instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2850: What is 820-2850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> A No <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Very new to board repair

Green Light on charger 

Decided to start with <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>

<RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>: 0 VOLTS
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>: 18.5V
<TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR>: SOURCE: 18.5V GATE: 17.88 DRAIN: 18.03
<TRANSISTOR>Q7085</TRANSISTOR>: SOURCE: 18.03V GATE: 17.23 DRAIN: 0V

<RESISTOR>R7085</RESISTOR> actually sparked when I tested it

<RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>: 0 VOLTS (<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_DCINRUSH</SIGNAL>)

<CHIP>U7000</CHIP>: RESISTANCE PINS 27-28 20.3 OHMS (CURRENT SENSING)

F7040 Fuse: pin 2: 0 V (starts at 1 and slowly drifts to 0)

<CHIP>U7000</CHIP>
PIN 14: <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL>: 3.27V
PIN 19: 5.1 V 



My thought is that <TRANSISTOR>Q7085</TRANSISTOR> is bad. Should have voltage going through it. Without that, no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>

Am I on the right track?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> A No <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<TRANSISTOR>Q7085</TRANSISTOR> is blocked; is controlled by <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.
Post basic voltages for <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>; pins 1, 2, 3, 9, 12, 13, 15, 17, 19, 20, 27.
Also post exact ohm resistance between pins 17/18.

Need to know exact values for <RESISTOR>R7085</RESISTOR>/86; ohm scale, measured onboard.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> A No <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Post basic voltages for <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>;
pins 

1: 16.70
2: 18.24
3: 0.206
9: 0.030
12: 3.412
13: 3.41
15: 0.048
17: 0.233
19: 5.115
20: 5.115
27: 0
28: 0

RESISTANCE 17/18: 3.5 ohm

<RESISTOR>R7085</RESISTOR>: 470 Kohm
<RESISTOR>R7086</RESISTOR>: 331 Kohm

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> A No <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"3: 0.206"
Missing ACIN, <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> doesn't work until fix this problem.
Check <RESISTOR>R7010</RESISTOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7011</CAPACITOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> A No <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7010</RESISTOR>: 4 kOhm
<RESISTOR>R7011</RESISTOR>: 330 Ohm
<CAPACITOR>C7011</CAPACITOR>: 0 uF

<RESISTOR>R7013</RESISTOR> is missing completely which makes no sense to me (I double and triple checked)
<RESISTOR>R7012</RESISTOR>: 1 kOhm

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> A No <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"<RESISTOR>R7011</RESISTOR>: 330 Ohm"
Do you mean onboard value?
Remove <CAPACITOR>C7011</CAPACITOR>.
If you still get the same value, change <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.

"<CAPACITOR>C7011</CAPACITOR>: 0 uF"
I was not thinking on its capacity...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> A No <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[B][I]"<RESISTOR>R7011</RESISTOR>: 330 Ohm"
Do you mean onboard value?

"<CAPACITOR>C7011</CAPACITOR>: 0 uF"
I was not thinking on its capacity...[/I][/B]

Were you asking about short to ground or?

Sorry, new to this but I do appreciate your time.
After your response I usually spend time looking at the schematic to figure how and why to ask the same question you did.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> A No <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
ACIN input measured on diode mode gave very low value on your board.
Only two options available:
- <CAPACITOR>C7011</CAPACITOR> leakage, can be discarded measuring after removed.
- <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> internal problems and needs change.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> A No <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
And:

<RESISTOR>R7013</RESISTOR> is missing completely ? any idea why. It is not a NOSTUFF on this board

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> A No <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7012</RESISTOR>/13 can NOT be present at same time.
<RESISTOR>R7012</RESISTOR> is for 3 cells battery and <RESISTOR>R7013</RESISTOR> for 2 cells battery.
If none present, <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> will deliver aprox 4V on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>; it will suppose 1 cell battery present...
